questions.text: A male child presented with easy bruisability leading to detailed investigations which revealed normal PT, prolonged APTT and normal bleeding time. Which of the following cannot be cause of his condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Von willebrand disease

 

The combination of normal prothrombin time (PT), prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT), and normal bleeding time indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, which includes factors VIII, IX, and XI.

 

  • Factor 8 deficiency (Hemophilia A), Factor 9 deficiency (Hemophilia B), and Factor 11 deficiency (Hemophilia C) all cause a prolonged APTT with normal PT and bleeding time.

 

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) affects both platelet function and the intrinsic pathway of coagulation, leading to an increased bleeding time and often a prolonged APTT. However, the presence of a normal bleeding time in this patient rules out vWD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Factor 8 deficiency: This would present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Option B. Factor 9 deficiency: This would also present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Option C. Factor 11 deficiency: This would similarly present with prolonged APTT and normal PT, consistent with the findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isolated increased APTT can be caused by clotting factor deficiency of the intrinsic pathway like hemophilia A/B/C. von Willebrand disease is associated with increased bleeding time and increased APTT.

questions.text:
You are a primary care physician seeing a patient for a routine check-up. The patient expresses concern about colon cancer and asks about potential risk factors and preventive measures. You provide the following information: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Right and left colon cancers can exhibit distinct behaviour.
  2. Colon cancer can have hereditary components.
  3. Colon cancer risk can be mitigated by metformin.
  4. Liver metastases are a common occurrence in colon cancer.

 

Which of the following options is/are true regarding colon cancer:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, and 4

 

All the 4 statements given are true about colon cancer.

 

  • Right and left colon cancers exhibit different characteristics, with left-sided tumors being more likely to cause obstruction due to the caliber of the bowel and consistency of stool.
  • Proximal colon cancers, or right colon cancers, are typically diagnosed later and may present with iron deficiency anemia or a mass.
  • While the majority of colorectal cancers occur sporadically, some can be hereditary and are more common in patients with a family history of the disease, like FAP and HNPCC. Genetic testing can aid in early diagnosis.
  • Metformin, a biguanide compound used to treat diabetes, has been shown to reduce the risk of colorectal cancer by disrupting cellular energy supply and inhibiting aerobic glycolysis.
  • Liver metastasis is the most frequent site of distant metastasis in colorectal cancer and occurs through hematogenous spread via the portal venous system. Tumor size and grade are risk factors. The second most common site of distant metastasis is the lung, while carcinomatosis can occur through peritoneal seeding.

questions.text: Which of the following does not play a role in fetal growth?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Growth hormone

 

Growth hormone (GH) does not play a significant role in fetal growth. The primary regulators of fetal growth are insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) and thyroxine. IGFs are critical for cellular growth and differentiation during fetal development. Thyroxine, a thyroid hormone, is essential for brain development and overall growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Insulin-like growth factors: These play a crucial role in fetal growth by promoting cellular growth and differentiation.

 

Option C. Thyroxine: This hormone is vital for proper development, particularly for brain development and metabolic regulation.

 

Option D. All of the above: This option is incorrect because growth hormone does not significantly influence fetal growth, while IGFs and thyroxine do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth hormone does not play a significant role in fetal growth, while insulin-like growth factors and thyroxine are crucial for proper fetal development.

questions.text: A young male presents to surgery OPD with a verrucous lesion over the penis as shown in the image. On examination, inguinal lymph nodes are not enlarged. What is the management of choice in this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) Partial penectomy

 

  • The question depicts a case of verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor.
  • Verrucous carcinoma is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that is locally aggressive but has a low potential for metastasis.
  • The lesion typically appears as a large, exophytic, cauliflower-like growth.
  • The management of choice for verrucous carcinoma of the penis is partial penectomy.
  • This surgical procedure involves removing the affected portion of the penis to ensure complete excision of the tumor while preserving as much of the penile structure and function as possible.
  • This approach helps in preventing local recurrence and provides a definitive treatment for the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CO2 laser ablation: CO2 laser ablation is a treatment option for in-situ carcinoma, such as Bowen’s disease or penile intra-epithelial neoplasm. It is effective in treating superficial lesions but is not adequate for managing verrucous carcinoma due to its deeper and locally invasive nature.

 

Option B. Podophylline: Podophylline is a topical treatment commonly used for genital warts caused by human papillomavirus (HPV). It is not appropriate for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires a more definitive surgical approach.

 

Option C. Topical 5-Fluoro uracil: Topical 5-Fluoro uracil is used in the treatment of in-situ carcinoma or Bowen’s disease. It is not suitable for treating verrucous carcinoma, which requires surgical excision due to its locally invasive nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verrucous carcinoma of the penis, also known as Buschke-Löwenstein tumor, is best managed by partial penectomy to ensure complete removal of the tumor and prevent local recurrence.
  • This approach is necessary due to the locally aggressive behavior of the tumor, which cannot be adequately treated with topical or minimally invasive methods.

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) West Nile Virus

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can cause neurological disease and death in people. WNV is commonly found in Africa, Europe, the Middle East, North America and West Asia. In Mumbai in the year 1952, the antibodies against WNV were first detected in humans. Since then, the virus activity has been reported in southern, central, and western India. WNV is maintained in nature in a cycle involving transmission between birds and mosquitoes. Humans, horses and other mammals can be infected.

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) is a member of the flavivirus genus and belongs to the Japanese encephalitis antigenic complex of the family Flaviviridae.

 

West Nile virus can be diagnosed by a number of different tests:

 

  • IgG antibody sero-conversion (or significant increase in antibody titers) in two serial specimen collected at a one week interval by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • IgM antibody capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA);
  • neutralisation assays;
  • viral detection by reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) assay, and
  • virus isolation by cell culture.

 

IgM can be detected in nearly all cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum specimens received from WNV infected patients at the time of their clinical presentation. Serum IgM antibody may persist for more than a year.

 

Other options:

 

Option A: Hendra virus is endemic to Australia

 

Option C: Ebola virus is endemic to Africa.

 

Option D: Yellow fever endemic to South and Central America, and certain parts of Africa.

 

Educational Objective

 

West Nile Virus (WNV) can be identified by PCR and is endemic to India, with significant historical and ongoing presence, making it a critical pathogen for regional public health monitoring and response.

questions.text: An infant came with vomiting, jaundice, and hypoglycemia. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Galactosemia

 

Galactosemia is a metabolic disorder characterized by the inability to metabolize galactose properly due to a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GALT). This leads to the accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate in various tissues, resulting in symptoms such as vomiting, jaundice, hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and oil droplet cataracts. The condition often presents in the neonatal period shortly after the introduction of milk or milk-based formulas, which contain lactose (broken down into glucose and galactose). The inability to process galactose leads to hypoglycemia due to disruption in normal glucose metabolism.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phenylketonuria: This condition involves a deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to elevated phenylalanine levels. Symptoms typically include intellectual disability, seizures, and a musty body odor, but not jaundice or hypoglycemia. There is no direct association with the symptoms of vomiting or jaundice seen in the presented case.

 

Option C. Wilson disease: Wilson disease is a genetic disorder that leads to copper accumulation, particularly in the liver and brain. Key symptoms include hepatic dysfunction, neurological symptoms like tremors (wing-beating tremors), and the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings in the eyes. However, it does not typically present with vomiting, jaundice, and hypoglycemia in infancy.

 

Option D. Menke disease: Menke disease is a disorder of copper transport, characterized by kinky hair, growth failure, and deterioration of the nervous system. It does not typically present with jaundice or hypoglycemia. The defining symptoms such as brittle, kinky hair were not noted in the question, making it less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Galactosemia should be suspected in infants presenting with vomiting, jaundice, and hypoglycemia, especially soon after the introduction of milk. Immediate dietary management with lactose-free formulas is critical to prevent complications.

questions.text: All of the following cranial nerve nuclei are part of special visceral afferent column except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trochlear nerve

 

The trochlear nerve nucleus belongs to the general somatic efferent column (GSE), not the special visceral afferent column. Special visceral afferent refers to sensory information associated with taste and smell.

 

The trochlear nerve is a motor nerve that innervates the orbit's superior oblique muscle.

 

The neurons of the general somatic efferent (GSE) column innervate the extrinsic ocular and tongue muscles (III, IV, VI, and XII cranial nerves).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial Nerve (CN VII):

 

  • Sensory Component: The facial nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue (via the chorda tympani branch).
  • Motor Component: The facial nerve also contains motor fibers responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression.

 

Option C. Vagus Nerve (CN X):

 

  • Sensory Component: The vagus nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the epiglottis and the root of the tongue.
  • Motor Component: The vagus nerve has a wide range of motor functions, including control of the muscles involved in swallowing and vocalization, as well as autonomic functions.

 

Option D. Glossopharyngeal Nerve (CN IX):

 

  • Sensory Component: The glossopharyngeal nerve carries special visceral afferent fibers responsible for taste sensation from the posterior one-third of the tongue and sensory input from the oropharynx.
  • Motor Component: It also has motor functions, including control of certain muscles involved in swallowing.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, direct Coombs test

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought with pallor and jaundice. On examination he had a hemoglobin of 9g/dl and mild splenomegaly. He has a history of similar episodes from birth.  The peripheral smear had red cells without central pallor. Which of the following is useful for making the diagnosis of the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hereditary spherocytosis, osmotic fragility test 

 

Presence of mild jaundice, splenomegaly and anemia is suggestive of hemolytic anemia with extravascular hemolysis. Since the history of similar episodes since child birth is present it is more likely a familiar case and so, the most appropriate answer is hereditary spherocytosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, direct Coombs test: While autoimmune hemolytic anemia also presents with hemolysis, the history of episodes from birth and the specific peripheral smear findings are more suggestive of hereditary spherocytosis.

 

Option C. Hemolytic uremic syndrome: Typically presents with acute kidney injury, thrombocytopenia, and microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, not with a chronic history from birth.

 

Option D. Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH): Characterized by intravascular hemolysis, hemoglobinuria, and a different set of laboratory findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hereditary spherocytosis should be suspected in patients with chronic hemolytic anemia, jaundice, splenomegaly, and spherocytes on a peripheral smear. The osmotic fragility test is a key diagnostic tool for this condition.

 

  • Spherocytes are more fragile in hypotonic solutions due to reduced surface area-to-volume ratio.
  • Newer and more sensitive tests include EMA (Eosin-5-maleimide) binding test by flow cytometry.

questions.text: Innervation of lateral rectus is by which nerve? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CN VI

 

The lateral rectus muscle, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally (abduction), is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve, also known as the abducens nerve. This nerve specifically controls the lateral rectus muscle, allowing for the lateral movement of the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CN III (Oculomotor nerve): The oculomotor nerve innervates most of the other extraocular muscles, including the medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, and inferior oblique muscles. It is not responsible for innervating the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Option B. CN IV (Trochlear nerve): The trochlear nerve innervates only the superior oblique muscle, which is involved in downward and outward movement of the eye. It does not innervate the lateral rectus muscle.

 

Option D. CN VII (Facial nerve): The facial nerve is primarily responsible for the muscles of facial expression. It does not innervate any of the extraocular muscles, including the lateral rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral rectus muscle is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve (CN VI), also known as the abducens nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with vitamin A deficiency? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bitot spots

 

Bitot spots are foamy, whitish accumulations on the conjunctiva of the eye and are caused by the keratinization of the epithelial cells. These spots are a specific sign of vitamin A deficiency, which is crucial for maintaining healthy epithelial tissues and normal vision. The deficiency leads to dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea, ultimately causing these characteristic spots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vogts stria: Vogts stria is associated with keratoconus, a condition where the cornea thins and gradually bulges outward into a cone shape, leading to vision problems.

 

Option B. Arlts line: Arlts line is related to trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis, leading to roughening of the inner surface of the eyelids.

 

Option D. Harnor tantra dots: Harnor tantra dots are focal white limbal dots consisting of degenerated epithelial cells and eosinophils, seen in vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin A deficiency is specifically associated with Bitot spots, characterized by keratin deposits on the conjunctiva.

questions.text: Which disease the girl is related to and what's her name? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sapna, Leprosy


The girl in the image is named Sapna, and she is associated with the National Leprosy Eradication Program. Sapna is an emblematic figure used to raise awareness about leprosy prevention and control through information, education, and communication (IEC) strategies. She symbolizes the message that leprosy is completely curable. Sapna herself is portrayed as a former leprosy patient who has been fully cured, aiming to reduce stigma and educate the public about the disease's curability.

 

National Leprosy Mission Trust of India is the agency who came out with the concept of the girl Sapna for Leprosy Awareness Efforts Generation.

 

Educational Objective:


Sapna is a character created to promote leprosy awareness and emphasize that leprosy is a 100% curable disease.

questions.text: Which nerve is most commonly damaged after parotid surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Facial nerve

 

The Facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII) is the most commonly damaged nerve during parotid gland surgery due to its anatomical course through the gland. Damage to this nerve can result in facial paralysis or weakness, affecting expressions and other functions like eyelid closure and stapedius muscle reflex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The Trigeminal nerve (Cranial Nerve V) is responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing. It is less commonly damaged during parotid surgery because of its location and the type of sensory and motor innervation it provides.

 

Option C. The Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX) is involved in taste on the posterior one-third of the tongue and swallowing. It is not typically at risk during parotid surgery as it does not traverse the parotid gland like the facial nerve.

 

Option D. The Accessory nerve (Cranial Nerve XI) innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles and is not usually at risk during parotid surgery because it does not run through the parotid gland.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Facial nerve is the most commonly damaged nerve during parotid surgery due to its anatomical path through the parotid gland, making it vulnerable to injury during surgical procedures involving this gland

questions.text: A middle aged man from West Bengal presents with paraesthesia of hands and feet, hyperkeratosis, lines in the nails and rain drop pigmentation in the hands. The most likely causative toxin for the above mentioned symptoms is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arsenic

 

The symptoms mentioned in the question are classic features of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Chronic Arsenic poisoning: It is insidious in nature. The onset of symptoms usually  occurs  after 2–8  weeks of exposure.  Chronic  poisoning  may  occur among persons engaged in smelting and refining of ores and in the subliming of arsenic in the manufacture of weed killers, dyes etc.

 

Clinical Features of Chronic Arsenic poisoning:

 

  1. GIT symptoms: loss of weight, malaise, loss of appetite, salivation, colicky pain, diarrhoea and vomiting.
  2. Liver: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
  3. Skin symptoms: usually begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (‘raindrops pigmentation). Skin cancer (Squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma) also occurs.
  4. Nails: Aldrich Mees lines (transverse  white  striae  of  the fingernails) may also be seen.
  5. Hairs: Alopecia occurs
  6. Hematological: Anemia, leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia and Bone marrow hypoplasia are  seen.  Anemia is normocytic and normochromic
  7.  Peripheral neuropathy: Sensory  and  motor  polyneuritis (sensory  symptoms  usually  predominate)  manifesting  as numbness and tingling in a ‘stocking glove’ distribution.
  8. Blackfoot disease: Due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.
  9. Encephalopathy
  10. Nephritis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead: Symptoms Abdominal pain, anemia, neurological deficits, but not specifically hyperkeratosis, Mees lines, or raindrop pigmentation.

 

Option C. Thallium: Symptoms Gastrointestinal disturbances, alopecia, peripheral neuropathy, but lacks the specific skin changes and nail lines associated with arsenic.

 

Option D. Mercury: Symptoms: Tremors, memory loss, gingivitis, and neurological symptoms, but does not cause hyperkeratosis or Mees lines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic arsenic poisoning presents with distinctive symptoms such as paraesthesia, hyperkeratosis, Aldrich Mees lines, and raindrop pigmentation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: In a 30-year-old female from a tribal area who presents with fever for the last 3 days, which of the following is the most likely causative agent of her illness based on the diagnosis of malaria made through examination of the peripheral smear? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P. falciparum

 

The image shows ring forms/ early trophozoites in erythrocyte, which are binucleate (double chromatin) resembling stereo headphones in appearance, characteristic of P. falciparum.

 

There may be several rings present within a single erythrocyte. The rings are often attached to the margins of the red cells and are described as form applique or accole.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P. malariae: Causes quartan malaria with a longer incubation period and typically presents with band-form trophozoites across the red cells, distinct from the forms seen in P. falciparum.

 

Option C. P. ovale: Known for causing tertian malaria with similar clinical presentations to P. vivax, including the presence of Schüffner's dots and slightly enlarged and ovale-shaped erythrocytes.

 

Option D. P. vivax: Also causes tertian malaria, characterized by Schüffner's stippling in erythrocytes, larger ring forms than P. falciparum, and less severe disease outcomes compared to P. falciparum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identification of P. falciparum through the presence of distinctive ring forms in red blood cells on a peripheral smear is crucial for rapid initiation of appropriate antimalarial therapy, particularly in endemic regions. Early treatment is vital to prevent severe complications and reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this malaria species.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old medical student developed epistaxis that resolved spontaneously. He has been afebrile for the last 24 hours and his platelet count is 14,000/µL. His BP is 110/70 mm of Hg and there is a 28% rise in hematocrit. What should be the management? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

1. Give 4 units of platelets

2. Give plenty of oral fluids

3. Give IV fluids

4. Keep under observation

5. Discharge the patient
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 3 and 4

 

The patient likely has Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever, indicated by a significant rise in hematocrit, which suggests plasma leakage during the critical phase of the illness. The management strategy includes:

 

  • Statement 2. Oral fluids to maintain hydration but must be balanced to avoid fluid overload.
  • Statement 3. IV fluids are essential for the management of severe dengue to correct the plasma leakage and prevent shock.
  • Statement 4. Observation is crucial to monitor for further complications such as dengue shock syndrome.

 

Option A. 1 and 2: Platelet transfusion is generally reserved for severe bleeding or very low platelet counts (typically <10,000/µL without bleeding). This patient's platelet count, while low, does not alone justify transfusion without signs of active or severe bleeding.

 

Option C. 1, 2 and 4: Includes unnecessary platelet transfusion without the clear presence of severe bleeding or extremely low platelet counts.

 

Option D. 2 and 5: Discharging the patient is inappropriate given the potential for rapid deterioration during the critical phase of dengue fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In dengue hemorrhagic fever, management focuses on careful fluid management and close observation during the critical phase to prevent or manage complications such as shock. Platelet transfusions are not routinely given based solely on low counts but are reserved for cases of significant clinical bleeding or extremely low platelet counts.

 

Note - There is no correlation between bleeding manifestation and platelet count.

 

Reference - Dengue Case management for Clinicians- CDC

questions.text: Nasal polyps are commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intrinsic asthma

 

Intrinsic asthma, also known as non-allergic asthma, is often associated with nasal polyps. This type of asthma does not have an allergic or atopic component and tends to develop in adulthood. Intrinsic asthma is characterized by a non-IgE mediated pathway involving eosinophils and neutrophils, often triggered by non-allergic factors such as viral infections, stress, or exercise. Nasal polyps in this context are linked to chronic inflammation of the sinuses and nasal passages, common in non-allergic forms of asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Brittle asthma: This is a term used to describe a severe form of asthma where patients experience frequent, severe exacerbations. While serious, it does not specifically correlate with the presence of nasal polyps more than other types of asthma.

 

Option C. Extrinsic asthma: Known as allergic asthma, it is mediated by IgE and typically involves allergen triggers like pollen, dust mites, and molds. Nasal polyps are less commonly associated with this subtype compared to intrinsic asthma.

 

Option D. Exercise-induced asthma: This condition, characterized by bronchoconstriction triggered by physical activity, is not typically associated with nasal polyps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Pulmonology/Asthma/Chap 287

questions.text: In Indian health care system, PHC are divided into Type A and Type B PHCs. Number of deliveries in Type A PHC: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Less than 20

 

In the Indian health care system, primary health centers (PHCs) are categorized into Type A and Type B based on the number of deliveries performed per month.

 

  • Type A PHCs handle less than 20 deliveries per month
  • Type B PHCs manage 20 or more deliveries per month.

 

This classification helps in resource allocation and planning to ensure adequate maternal and child health services are provided at the PHC level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the Indian health care system, Type A PHCs are those that handle less than 20 deliveries per month, while Type B PHCs manage 20 or more deliveries per month.

choices.text: If a and c are correct
If a, b and c are correct
a, b, c, & d are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following is correctly matched?

 

  1. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion
  2. Glucose: facilitated diffusion
  3. Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport
  4. Na: Secondary Active transport
questions.solution:
Ans. D) a, b, c, & d are correct

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Oxygen: Simple Diffusion: Oxygen is transported by simple passive diffusion based on the concentration gradient. This process does not require any energy input and relies on the natural movement of oxygen molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration.

 

Option B. Glucose: facilitated diffusion: Glucose is transported by facilitated diffusion using glucose transporters (GLUTs) and also through Na-dependent transport using sodium-glucose co-transporters (SGLT). GLUTs facilitate glucose transport without energy, while SGLT uses the sodium gradient to transport glucose into cells.

 

Option C. Na-dependent Calcium: Active transport: Calcium is transported by active transport mechanisms, which require energy. These mechanisms include:

  1. Plasma membrane Ca2+ ATPase (PMCA), which pumps calcium out of the cell.
  2. Sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX), which exchanges intracellular calcium for extracellular sodium. Additionally, calcium can be transported via receptor-mediated mechanisms, such as the IP3 receptor, facilitating calcium transport from the smooth endoplasmic reticulum (SER) to the mitochondria.

 

Option D. Na: Secondary Active transport: Sodium often moves down its gradient, but it is also involved in secondary active transport to drive uptake of other substances against their gradients (e.g., glucose in intestines).
The Na⁺/glucose symporter (SGLT) is a classic example.
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Each substance (oxygen, glucose, calcium, and sodium) has specific and correct transport mechanisms: oxygen by simple diffusion, glucose by facilitated and Na-dependent transport, calcium by active transport, and sodium by secondary active transport.

 

Reference: Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/pg-639

questions.text: Which of the following layers is responsible for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endothelium

 

  • The endothelial cells of the cornea maintain its hydration/deturgescence level and transparency.
  • Overhydration of the cornea can lead to light scattering and loss of transparency.
  • Endothelium has Na+/K+ ATPase which keeps the cornea deturgescent, maintaining its transparency.
  • The number of endothelial cells decreases with age.
  • Regular arrangement and peculiar refractive index of corneal lamellae, avascularity of the cornea, and a balance between intraocular pressure and swelling pressure also contribute to corneal transparency.

 

The different layers of cornea:

 

  • Epithelium - It is of stratified squamous type and becomes continuous with the epithelium of bulbar conjunctiva at the limbus. It consists of 5-6 layers of cells. The deepest (basal) layer is made up of columnar cells, next 2-3 layers of wing or umbrella cells and the most superficial two layers are of flattened cells.
  • Bowman's membrane - This layer consists of acellular mass of condensed collagen fibrils. Bowman’s membrane cannot regenerate after corneal surgery.
  • Stroma (substantia propria) - Consists of collagen fibrils (lamellae) embedded in hydrated matrix of proteoglycans.
  • Dua's layer (pre-Descemet's layer)
  • Descemet's membrane - Consists of collagen and glycoproteins. Unlike Bowman's membrane it can regenerate.
  • Endothelium - Consists of a single layer of flat polygonal (mainly hexagonal) cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Descemet's membrane: Provides structural support but does not actively maintain corneal deturgescence.

 

Option C. Stroma: Contains collagen fibrils essential for structural integrity and transparency, but its hydration is controlled by the endothelium.

 

Option D. Corneal epithelium: Acts as a barrier to infection and injury but does not play a primary role in maintaining corneal hydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The corneal endothelium is crucial for maintaining the deturgescence and transparency of the cornea through active ion pumping mechanisms, ensuring proper hydration levels to prevent light scattering and maintain clarity.

choices.text: Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

questions.text: A 25-year-old male individual arrived at the emergency room following a road traffic accident, displaying signs indicative of a potential pelvic fracture. Upon assessment, he was determined to be experiencing hypovolemic shock. What is the initial course of action for managing hemorrhage control in this scenario? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis

 

In the immediate aftermath of a traumatic injury where a pelvic fracture is suspected, binding the pelvis with sheets (or commercial binders, if available) is a quick and effective way to provide temporary stabilization and reduce ongoing bleeding. This technique uses the concept of tamponading or compressing the bleeding vessels within the pelvis, which can be life-saving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Immediate internal fixation: This involves surgical stabilization of the pelvic fracture. While internal fixation might ultimately be necessary, it's not the initial action. Operating on an unstable patient can lead to further complications.

 

Option B. Multiple blood transfusions: Transfusing blood is critical for a patient in hypovolemic shock due to bleeding. However, it addresses the consequence (loss of blood) rather than the cause (active bleeding from the fracture). Stopping or controlling the bleed is paramount.

 

Option D. Emergency external fixation: External fixators can be applied to stabilize the pelvis and control hemorrhage. While this is a more definitive action than using bedsheets, it requires more time, equipment, and a surgical setting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Given the acute nature of the presentation and the need for immediate action to address life-threatening bleeding, the primary and fastest step would be C) Use bedsheets to compress the pelvis. This is a temporizing measure that can stabilize the patient until more definitive interventions (like external or internal fixation) can be safely undertaken.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fixed central airway obstruction


The flow-volume loop shows flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is characteristic of a fixed central airway obstruction. This pattern suggests an obstruction that affects airflow both during inhalation and exhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fixed distal airway obstruction would not typically affect both phases of the loop.

 

Option C. Variable intrathoracic obstruction affects the expiratory phase more.

 

Option D. Variable extrathoracic obstruction affects the inspiratory phase more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs in a flow-volume loop indicates a fixed central airway obstruction.

choices.text: Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation

questions.text: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aortic regurgitation

 

A water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan pulse, is characterized by a rapid and forceful rise in pulse with a quick collapse. It is typically seen in aortic regurgitation. This phenomenon occurs due to the regurgitation of blood from the aorta back into the left ventricle during diastole, leading to an increased stroke volume and a subsequent forceful arterial pulse that collapses suddenly as the blood quickly flows back into the ventricle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic stenosis: In aortic stenosis, the pulse is described as pulsus parvus et tardus—'small and slow,' reflecting the reduced and delayed pulse wave due to the obstruction across the aortic valve.

 

Option C. Aortic stenosis and aortic regurgitation: When these two conditions coexist, the pulse is known as pulsus bisferiens, which is characterized by a double peak per cardiac cycle—not the rapid rise and fall typical of a water hammer pulse.

 

Option D. Mitral regurgitation: In mitral regurgitation, the pulse may be described as hyperkinetic due to the increased volume load on the left ventricle, but it does not exhibit the rapid collapse seen in water hammer pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The water hammer pulse is a distinctive physical finding primarily associated with aortic regurgitation and is useful in the physical diagnosis of this condition. This type of pulse helps clinicians in the assessment of the severity and impact of valve dysfunction on the cardiovascular system.

 

Reference - Harrison/Clinical Cardiology/Chap 239

questions.text: A 80 year old male presented with diminution of vision since 2 years. The right eye was red and painful. On examination, the IOP was 50 mmHg in right eye and 16 mmHg in left eye. The right eye had deep anterior chamber with some cells and flare. What could be the possibility? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacolytic glaucoma

 

Phacolytic glaucoma is characterized by the leakage of lens proteins through an intact lens capsule, which causes an inflammatory response in the eye. This condition often occurs in elderly patients with hypermature cataracts. The leakage of proteins results in cells and flare in the anterior chamber, as well as a deep anterior chamber. The clinical presentation described in the question, including the deep anterior chamber with cells and flare and the patient's age, aligns with the characteristics of phacolytic glaucoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malignant glaucoma: Malignant glaucoma, also known as aqueous misdirection syndrome, is characterized by a shallow anterior chamber and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP). This condition typically does not present with cells and flare in the anterior chamber, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this case.

 

Option C. Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis: Fuch heterochromic iridocyclitis usually presents in younger patients, and it is less likely to occur in an 80-year-old individual. This condition is characterized by heterochromia (difference in eye color) and mild anterior uveitis, but it does not typically present with the deep anterior chamber and the level of inflammation described in the question.

 

Option D. Phacomorphic glaucoma: Phacomorphic glaucoma occurs due to the swelling of a mature cataract, which leads to a shallow anterior chamber and increased IOP. The question describes a deep anterior chamber, which is not consistent with phacomorphic glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phacolytic glaucoma presents with a deep anterior chamber, cells and flare due to leakage of lens proteins, and typically occurs in elderly patients with hypermature cataracts.

questions.text: Which of the following would most likely lead to a decrease in the intensity of the murmur in a patient with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Squatting

 

In hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM), the intensity of the murmur is influenced by the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction. Various maneuvers and medications can affect this obstruction by altering preload (the volume of blood in the ventricles before contraction) or afterload (the resistance the heart must pump against).

 

Squatting increases preload by squeezing the peripheral veins and increasing venous return to the heart. This increase in preload reduces LVOT obstruction, thereby decreasing the murmur's intensity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: Digoxin increases contractility. In HCM, increased contractility can worsen LVOT obstruction, thereby increasing the intensity of the murmur and worsening the murmur.

 

Option C. Valsalva: The Valsalva maneuver reduces preload by decreasing venous return to the heart. This reduction in preload can increase LVOT obstruction, leading to a louder murmur.

 

Option D. Furosemide: By reducing preload, furosemide increases LVOT obstruction and murmur intensity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increasing preload (e.g., through squatting) reduces LVOT obstruction in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, leading to a decrease in the murmur's intensity.

questions.text: The Honorable Supreme Court of India has banned one of the following, which is infamous among doctors for sexual assault cases: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Two finger test

 

The Supreme Court of India has banned the two-finger test, which was infamous in sexual assault cases. The rationale behind the test was that by inserting two fingers into the vagina, the examiner could determine if a woman was "habituated to sex." If two fingers could be inserted, it was assumed that the woman was sexually active; if only one finger could be inserted, it suggested that she was not.

 

This test was criticized for several reasons:

 

  1. Irrelevance to the Current Case: The past sexual behavior of the victim has no bearing on the facts of the current case of sexual assault. The test does not provide any information relevant to determining whether a rape occurred.
  2. Character Judgment: The test was used to infer the character of the woman, which is derogatory and not permissible. It essentially judged the woman based on her sexual history, which is irrelevant and discriminatory.
  3. Psychological Harm: The test could cause additional trauma to the victim, compounding the psychological harm already experienced due to the assault.

 

The Supreme Court's ruling emphasized that the past sexual behavior of a woman should not be documented or examined as it has no relevance to the current case of rape. The focus should be on the incident in question, not on the victim's sexual history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foley's catheter insertion: This is a medical procedure used to drain the bladder and is unrelated to assessing sexual history or assault.

 

Option B. Colposcopy: This is a medical diagnostic procedure to examine an illuminated, magnified view of the cervix and the tissues of the vagina and vulva. It is used in cases of abnormal Pap smears and is not used for determining past sexual behavior.

 

Option C. PV speculum: The use of a speculum is part of a gynecological exam to inspect the vaginal and cervical areas. It is a routine medical examination tool and does not relate to assessing sexual history or habits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The two-finger test, previously used to assess whether a woman was "habituated to sex," has been banned by the Supreme Court of India due to its irrelevance, discriminatory nature, and potential to cause additional trauma to sexual assault victims.

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:

 

  • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor: While acyclovir is appropriate for treating HSV, inducing labor is not recommended due to the high risk of neonatal infection with vaginal delivery in the presence of active primary HSV lesions.

 

Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Spontaneous vaginal delivery poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can lead to severe complications and high mortality. This is not recommended in the case of primary genital HSV.

 

Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Antiviral treatment is necessary, but normal vaginal delivery is not recommended due to the high risk of transmitting HSV to the neonate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of primary genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at term, the best treatment option is to start antiviral therapy and plan for an elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes infection.

 

Ref: Page no 673, High Risk Pregnancy: Management Options; David James, Philip J Steer; 5th edition

questions.text: Identify the source of trauma in the image below. (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bullet

 

The image shows a circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull, which is characteristic of a bullet wound. Beveling of the outer table indicates an exit wound, while beveling of the inner table would indicate an entry wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scissor: Incorrect. Scissor injuries typically produce irregular, non-circular wounds with sharp edges, not the circular hole seen in the image.

 

Option B. Rod: Incorrect. Injuries from a rod would usually result in linear or irregular wounds, depending on the shape and force of impact, not a circular hole.

 

Option C. Axe: Incorrect. An axe would cause a large, irregular, and typically more extensive laceration with sharp, defined edges, not a circular hole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A circular hole with beveling on the outer table of the skull is indicative of a bullet wound, specifically an exit wound.

questions.text: To which organism does the provided image of the cell wall belong? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitides

 

  • The displayed picture illustrates a cell wall of a gram negative bacteria
  • It shows presence of  lipooligosaccharides (LOS), which strongly indicates the presence of Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Unlike lipopolysaccharide (LPS), LOS lacks a lengthy 0-antigen side chain.
  • This unique characteristic makes it a significant virulence factor, observed in only a limited number of organisms, including N. gonorrhoeae, N. meningitidis, H. ducreyi, and others.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Staphylococcus aureus is a gram-positive bacterium and does not have a cell wall structure similar to the one depicted.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS instead of LOS.

 

Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium, but it has LPS rather than LOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis is identified by the presence of lipooligosaccharides (LOS) in its cell wall, a distinguishing feature of this gram-negative bacterium.

questions.text: You are working as an ER physician, and a patient with a laceration has just been brought in. You decide to use the interrupted suturing technique to close the wound. As you prepare to suture, you recall that the angle of needle placement is crucial for optimal wound closure. What is the correct angle of needle placement for interrupted suturing technique? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 90 degrees

 

This is the correct angle because inserting the needle perpendicular to the skin (at a 90-degree angle) ensures optimal tissue eversion and approximation of the wound edges. It allows for consistent depth and distance from the wound edge on both the entry and exit points of the needle, which is crucial for the interrupted suturing technique to effectively close the wound.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To properly execute interrupted sutures, it is recommended that the needle is inserted and exited the skin at a right angle (90 degrees). It is important to rotate the needle through the tissue to prevent unnecessary enlargement of the needle hole. The distance between the entry point of the suture and the edge of the wound should be nearly equal to the depth of tissue that is being sutured. Additionally, it is advised to leave a distance that is twice this measurement between two consecutive sutures.

questions.text: All of the following are true about NF-1 EXCEPT: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal recessive

 

The correct answer is autosomal recessive. Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1) is an autosomal dominant disorder, not autosomal recessive. It is characterized by multiple café-au-lait macules, Lisch nodules, and an increased risk of developing various tumors, including optic gliomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Optic glioma: This is true. Patients with NF-1 have an increased risk of developing optic gliomas.

 

Option C. CALM (Cafe Au Lait Macules): This is true. Café-au-lait macules are a common feature of NF-1.

 

Option D. Lisch nodules: This is true. Lisch nodules are iris hamartomas commonly seen in patients with NF-1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF-1) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by features such as café-au-lait macules, Lisch nodules, and optic gliomas. It is important to remember that it is not autosomal recessive.

questions.text: Based on the agglutination test shown below, what is the blood group?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. O positive

 

The agglutination test is a blood test used to determine an individual's blood type. In the case of O positive blood, the test involves mixing a sample of the person's blood with two different types of antibodies: anti-A and anti-B.

 

The person's blood cells do not agglutinate in the presence of either antibody, it indicates that the person's blood type is O positive. This means that the person's blood cells do not contain either the A or B antigen, but do contain the Rh factor antigen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. B positive: Incorrect because there is no agglutination in the B panel, indicating the absence of B antigens.

 

Option B. A positive: Incorrect as there is no agglutination in the A panel, indicating the absence of A antigens.

 

Option D. AB positive: Incorrect because there is no agglutination in both A and B panels, which would be required for AB blood type.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of agglutination with anti-A and anti-B antibodies and the presence of agglutination with anti-Rh antibodies confirms the blood group as O positive. This means the individual's red blood cells lack A and B antigens but contain the Rh factor.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an amphipathic Lipid? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Triglycerides

 

  • Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids. They consist of three fatty acid chains esterified to a glycerol molecule. These molecules are hydrophobic and do not have a polar or hydrophilic region. Triglycerides are the primary storage form of energy in the body and are commonly found in adipose tissue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Phosphoglycerol: Phosphoglycerol, also known as phosphoglyceride or glycerophospholipid, is an amphipathic lipid. It has a polar phosphate head group and two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Phosphoglycerides are essential components of cell membranes, where they form the lipid bilayer.

 

Option C. Glycolipids: Glycolipids are amphipathic lipids. They have a hydrophilic carbohydrate (sugar) head group and hydrophobic lipid tails. Glycolipids are important in cell membranes, particularly in nerve cells and the myelin sheath. They play a role in cell signaling and recognition.

 

Option D. Sphingolipids: Sphingolipids are amphipathic lipids. They consist of a sphingosine backbone, a hydrophilic head group (usually containing a sugar), and one or two hydrophobic fatty acid tails. Sphingolipids are crucial components of cell membranes and are involved in various cellular processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triglycerides are not amphipathic lipids, while phosphoglycerol, glycolipids, and sphingolipids are amphipathic and play important roles in cell membrane structure and function.

 

They are formed by esterification between three Fatty acids and one glycerol molecule. As Ester bond is non-polar so, molecule of TG is a non-polar. They are also called as neutral fats.

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery leading to bleeding in epidural space
Bridging veins leading to bleeding in epidural space
Circle of Willis leading to bleeding in Subarachnoid space
Anterior cerebral artery leading to bleeding in subdural space

questions.text: Which of the following is the bleeding vessel in extradural hemorrhage? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Middle meningeal artery leading to bleeding in epidural space

 

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH), also known as epidural hemorrhage, is typically caused by the rupture of the middle meningeal artery, which is a branch of the internal maxillary artery. This type of hemorrhage occurs between the dura mater and the skull. The arterial origin of this bleed results in a rapidly expanding hematoma, which can lead to increased intracranial pressure and requires prompt medical attention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bridging veins leading to bleeding in epidural space: Bridging veins, when ruptured, lead to subdural hemorrhage (SDH) rather than epidural hemorrhage.

 

Option C. Circle of Willis leading to bleeding in Subarachnoid space: The Circle of Willis is associated with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), not extradural hemorrhage. Bleeding from this area typically involves the rupture of aneurysms.

 

Option D. Anterior cerebral artery leading to bleeding in subdural space: The anterior cerebral artery, if involved in bleeding, does not cause subdural hemorrhage; instead, subdural hemorrhage is usually caused by the rupture of bridging veins.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Key points:

 

  • Subdural Hematoma (SDH): Typically caused by trauma, specifically related to tearing of bridging veins.
  • Epidural Hematoma (EDH): Always due to trauma and specifically linked to arterial damage, often involving the middle meningeal artery, a branch of the internal maxillary artery.
  • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): Mostly associated with trauma, with bridging veins being the common source. However, SAH can also be non-traumatic, often resulting from rupture of berry aneurysms.

questions.text:
Which of the following equipment is required for putting intravenous cannula in a newborn?(INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. 22G cannula

  2. 24G IV cannula

  3. 5-mL syringe

  4. Adhesive tape

  5. Normal saline
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2,3,4,5

 

Explanation:

 

2. 24G IV cannula: This refers to a 24-gauge (24G) cannula, which is typically used for neonates and infants due to its smaller diameter, making it suitable for their small and fragile veins.

3. 5-mL syringe: While placing an IV cannula, it's essential to have a syringe attached. The syringe helps to test the patency of the cannula once it's in the vein (flashback of blood can be seen), and it also assists in gently flushing the cannula with normal saline to ensure it's correctly positioned.

4. Adhesive tape: Once the cannula is in position, adhesive tape or a securement device is necessary to stabilize and fix the cannula in place, preventing it from dislodging.

5. Normal saline: Normal saline is used for flushing the cannula once it's in place to ensure patency. It's also utilized to keep the cannula patent if it's not immediately hooked up to an IV line.

 

Other Option:

 

1. 22G IV cannula: A 22-gauge (22G) cannula is larger and may be used for older infants or children but is often too large for a newborn's tiny veins. Hence, it is not typically used for neonates.

 

Educational Objective :

 

For placing an IV cannula in a newborn, the equipment required includes a 24G needle, a 5-mL syringe, adhesive tape, and normal saline.

choices.text: If replacement feeding, the neonate should be tested for HIV, if negative, ART is not required.
In exclusive breastfeeding, give nevirapine for 6 months only when baby is positive
If replacement feeding, the neonate need not receive nevirapine if HIV negative
If exclusive replacement feeding, give nevirapine for 6 weeks, even if the baby is negative

questions.text: A pediatrician is providing counselling to a pregnant woman who is HIV positive about postnatal care for her soon-to-be-born child. Which of the following statements best captures the recommended management for an infant born to a mother with HIV regarding antiretroviral treatment (ART)? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) If exclusive replacement feeding, give nevirapine for 6 weeks, even if the baby is negative

 

The baby should be given prophylaxis irrespective of feeding status and HIV status at birth.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. If replacement feeding, the neonate should be tested for HIV, if negative, ART is not required: Incorrect. Prophylaxis with nevirapine should still be given for 6 weeks regardless of HIV status.

 

Option B. In exclusive breastfeeding, give nevirapine for 6 months only when baby is positive: Incorrect. Nevirapine is given as prophylaxis irrespective of the infant's HIV status.

 

Option C. If replacement feeding, the neonate need not receive nevirapine if HIV negative: Incorrect. Prophylaxis should still be provided for 6 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infants of HIV-positive mothers on exclusive replacement feeding get 6-week nevirapine, regardless of their HIV status.

questions.text: A Patient is infected with a dimorphic fungus which involves the subcutaneous layers, identify the organism responsible for it? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sporothrix

 

The clinical presentation suggests an infection with a dimorphic fungus that primarily affects the subcutaneous layers.

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus known for causing subcutaneous infections. It spreads via lymphatic channels to the lymph nodes and is commonly associated with "rose gardener's disease."

 

Key Points about Sporothrix schenckii:

 

  • Dimorphic Nature: Sporothrix schenckii can exist in both mold and yeast forms.
  • Subcutaneous Infection: Typically causes chronic skin infections and spreads through lymphatic channels.
  • Common Name: Often referred to as "rose gardener's disease" due to its association with thorn pricks.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: Incorrect. Blastomyces dermatitidis is a dimorphic fungus but typically causes pulmonary and disseminated infections, not primarily subcutaneous infections.

 

Option B. Chromoblastomycosis: Incorrect. Chromoblastomycosis is caused by several dematiaceous (darkly pigmented) fungi, such as Fonsecaea pedrosoi, and is not dimorphic.

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: Incorrect. Rhinosporidiosis is caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, which is not a dimorphic fungus and typically causes polypoidal masses in mucous membranes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that causes subcutaneous infections, commonly known as "rose gardener's disease," and spreads via lymphatic channels.

 

Examples of dimorphic fungi - Coccidioides, Paracoccidioides, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Histoplasma capsulatum, Sporothrix schenckii

questions.text: Identify the instrument: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nasopharyngeal airway

 

The instrument shown in the image is a nasopharyngeal airway (NPA). This is a flexible, soft tube that is inserted through the nostril into the nasopharynx to secure an open airway. NPAs are particularly useful in situations where the patient is conscious or semi-conscious and may not tolerate an oropharyngeal airway due to a gag reflex. It is also useful when the oral route is not accessible or practical.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oropharyngeal airway:

 

 

Option B. Ovassapian airway:  The Ovassapian airway is a specific type of oropharyngeal airway designed for fiberoptic intubation.

 

 

Option D. Uncuffed endotracheal tube

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nasopharyngeal airway (NPA) is a flexible tube used to secure an airway via the nasal passage, especially in patients who are semi-conscious and have an intact gag reflex.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with spotting PV following insertion of an IUD. What is the best management? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iron supplementation

 

This is the recommendation by the ministry of health and family welfare. Usually spotting settles done in a few months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remove the IUD: Removal of the IUD is not indicated for mild spotting. It is a normal response and should be managed conservatively.

 

Option C. Oral antibiotics: Antibiotics are not required unless there is evidence of an infection, which is not indicated by mere spotting.

 

Option D. Reassurance and observe: Spotting following the insertion of an intrauterine device (IUD) is a common and expected side effect. It typically occurs due to the body's inflammatory response to the new device in the uterus, which can cause mild cramping and spotting. The best management in this situation is to reassure the patient and observe the symptoms. Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can be given to alleviate cramps and reduce spotting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron supplementation are crucial in managing post-IUCD insertion bleeding to prevent anemia. If bleeding persists, further action, such as removing the IUCD, may be necessary.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male underwent NCCT abdomen for suspected renal calculi. An incidental finding was noted in the liver. What is the likely diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hydatid cyst

 

Explanation:

 

The above CT image showing a calcified lesion in the liver with a lamellar wall which indicates hydatid disease.

 

Caused by Echinococcus granulosus → Humans – accidental host

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatocellular carcinoma: Typically presents as a solid tumor with irregular borders and might show vascular invasion or enhancement after contrast administration, not typically calcified.

 

Option B. Fibronodular hyperplasia: Refers to a benign liver lesion that generally does not demonstrate the clear, calcified, and layered appearance of a hydatid cyst.

 

Option C. Liver abscess: Would more likely present as a fluid-filled lesion with possible air-fluid levels and peripheral enhancement after contrast, not the lamellar calcification seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydatid cysts in the liver are recognized on CT scans by their calcified, lamellar structure and are an important differential when considering cystic liver lesions, particularly in regions where Echinococcus is endemic.

questions.text: A couple presents to the infertility clinic with a normal hysterosalpingogram and a semen analysis report with azoospermia. Which of the following test is useful to differentiate between an obstructive and a testicular cause? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Testicular Biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

  • The absence of sperm in semen is known as azoospermia. It can be due to:
    • Pre-testicular azoospermia due to a hypothalamic or pituitary abnormality (hypogonadotropic hypogonadism)
    • Testicular failure or non-obstructive azoospermia
    • Post-testicular obstruction implies normal spermatogenesis but failure to deliver the sperm into the ejaculate because of ducal obstruction.
  • In testicular cause of azoospermia, there will be absent or very few sperms on biopsy whereas in obstructive azoospermia, there will be normal sperms on biopsy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum FSH levels and Option B. Serum testosterone levels are important for spermatogenesis

 

  • FSH levels can be used to differentiate hypogonadotrophic hypogonadism from other causes of testicular failure

 

Option D. Serum LH level: LH is a non-specific test in evaluation of azoospermia

 

Educational Objective:

 

A testicular biopsy is useful to differentiate between an obstructive and a testicular cause of Azoospermia.

 

Ref: Page no 233, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6the edition
